sect1.title: Ajustando o Conjunto de Ferramentas
sect1.para: Now that the final C libraries have been installed, it is time to adjust the toolchain so that it will link any newly compiled program against these new libraries.
First, backup the /tools linker, and replace it with the adjusted linker we made in chapter 5. We'll also create a link to its counterpart in /tools/$(uname -m)-pc-linux-gnu/bin:

the next command amends the GCC specs file to achieve three goals: first point GCC to the new dynamic linker. Simply deleting all instances of /tools should leave us with the correct path to the dynamic linker. Second, let GCC know where to find the Glibc start files. Third, add the /usr/include directory at the end of the default search path, so that header files added in chapter 6 are found. A sed command accomplishes this:
It is a good idea to visually inspect the specs file to verify the intended change was actually made.
It is imperative at this point to ensure that the basic functions (compiling and linking) of the adjusted toolchain are working as expected. To do this, perform the following sanity checks:

screen.userinput: echo 'int main(){}' > dummy.c cc dummy.c -v -Wl,--verbose &> dummy.log readelf -l a.out | grep ': /lib'

sect1.para: Deveriam não existir erros, e a saída do último comando será (permitindo diferenças específicas de plataforma no nome de vinculador dinâmico):
Note that on 64-bit systems /lib is the location of our dynamic linker, but is accessed via a symbolic link in /lib64.

note.para: On 32-bit systems the interpreter should be /lib/ld-linux.so.2.
